entry.title: About
entry.content:
I am a first year MS/PhD student in the College of Information and Computer Sciences at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst. My interests are around a branch of Artificial Intelligence known as continual learning. It aims at making the machines understand new concepts over time. I work at the intersection of reinforcement learning, deep learning, and online optimization. Often I look out for inspirations from neuroscience as well.

I graduated from VIT University in 2017 with bachelors in Computer Science. I did my undergrad research project at IIT-Madras under the amazing guidance of Prof. B. Ravindran. In 2016, I had wonderful opportunities of doing research internships at Defence Research and Development Organization(IRDE, DRDO) under Dr. J.P. Singh and later at University of Technology, France under Prof. Babiga Birregah. As a sophomore, I was lucky to be a part of Aspiring Researcher’s Challenge and being guided by Prof. James Davis, UCSC and Rajan Vaish, Stanford.


Talks


Life-long learning, avoiding catastrophic forgetting in Neural Netowrks.
Lab talk at IIT-Madras, 2017. Slides

Inline HTML elements

HTML defines a long list of available inline tags, a complete list of which can be found on the Mozilla Developer Network.

  • To bold text, use <strong>.
  • To italicize text, use <em>.
  • Abbreviations, like HTML should use <abbr>, with an optional title attribute for the full phrase.
  • Citations, like — Mark otto, should use <cite>.
  • Deleted text should use <del> and inserted text should use <ins>.
  • Superscript text uses <sup> and subscript text uses <sub>.

Most of these elements are styled by browsers with few modifications on our part.
